question.text: All of the following are cell types found in the stomach EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: Within the folds of the stomach are gastric glands containing various types of cells. Mucous cells secrete mucus which serve to lubricate and protect the lining of the stomach from the highly acidic juices of the stomach. Parietal cells secrete hydrochloric acid, as well as intrinsic factor.  The acidic hydrochloric acid (HCl) is responsible for the activation of pepsinogen into its active form pepsin, as well as the breakdown of proteins. Intrinsic factor ensures that vitamin B12 gets absorbed in the small intestine. Chief cells secrete pepsinogen and gastric lipase. Pepsinogen is the zymogen (inactive precursor) of pepsin which is a protease responsible for the breakdown of proteins. Gastric lipase is involved in the breakdown of fats. G cells secrete the hormone gastrin.  Gastrin has multiple functions, one of which is the stimulation of parietal cells to secrete hydrochloric acid. Gastrin also functions to stimulate chief cells to secrete pepsinogen and gastric lipase. Goblet cells are NOT found in the stomach. Goblet cells are found in the small intestine and are responsible for the secretion of mucus in order to protect the epithelial lining of the small intestine. Because goblet cells are not found in the stomach, Option E . is the correct answer to this question.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Mucous cells – This option is incorrect Mucous cells do in fact exist in the stomach. Mucous cells are responsible for the production and secretion of mucus which lubricates as well as protects the lining of the stomach from the acidic environment. Option B. Chief cells – This option is incorrect. Chief cells exist in the stomach and are stimulated by gastrin to secrete pepsinogen and gastric lipase. Pepsinogen is a zymogen (inactive precursor) and gets converted into the active form pepsin via the acidic environment within the stomach. Pepsin functions to digest proteins while gastric lipase functions to digest fats. Option C. Parietal cell – This option is incorrect. Parietal cells are cells of the stomach that secrete hydrochloric acid (HCl) and intrinsic factor. HCl creates an acidic environment within the stomach that converts pepsinogen into pepsin. In addition, HCl assists with the denaturation and digestion of proteins and the destruction of pathogens. Intrinsic factor ensures that vitamin B12 gets absorbed in the small intestine. Option D. G cells – This option is incorrect. G cells are cells of the stomach responsible for the secretion of gastrin (a hormone). Gastrin has multiple functions, one of which is the stimulation of parietal cells to secrete hydrochloric acid. Gastrin also functions to stimulate chief cells to secrete pepsinogen and gastric lipase.

question.text: All of the following contribute to the circulation of lymph throughout the body EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: Recall that nutrients are exchanged between the circulatory system and target tissues at the capillaries . At the arteriole end of the capillary, fluid is pushed out of the blood vessel via hydrostatic pressure. Fluid is then pulled back into the blood vessel on the venule end of the capillary via osmotic pressure, however, not ALL of the fluid in the interstitial space is pulled back into the blood vessels. Instead, the remaining interstitial fluid enters lymphatic vessels where the fluid becomes what is known as lymph . Some of the functions of the lymphatic system include preventing the buildup of excess fluid in tissues (swelling), immune function via lymph nodes, and the transportation of absorbed fat from the small intestine to the blood. There are some general details about the lymphatic system that you should know for your test: It is also important to note that the lymphatic system lacks a central pump, such as the heart. Therefore, lymph is pushed through lymphatic vessels in two primary ways. Similar to the veins in the blood circulatory system, skeletal muscle contractions will push lymph through the lymphatic vessels via the skeletal muscle pump . Lymphatic vessels also possess smooth muscles which push lymph through the vessels via peristalsis . Lymph nodes are NOT able to contract and do NOT contribute to the movement of lymph; therefore, Option D . is the correct answer to this question.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Location of re-entry – This option is incorrect. The lymphatic system is a low-pressure system and therefore, lymph must reenter the blood circulation in a low-pressure area. Recall that venous circulation is also low-pressure. Therefore, lymph reenters the blood circulation near the heart at the end of venous circulation, specifically, into the left and right subclavian vein. Because the location of re-entry MUST be in a low-pressure area, the location of re-entry does affect the circulation of lymph throughout the body. Option B. Smooth muscle contractions – This option is incorrect. Recall that the lymphatic system does not have a central pump, like the heart. Instead of a central pump, the contraction of skeletal muscles will push lymph through the lymphatic vessels via the skeletal muscle pump. In addition, lymphatic vessels possess smooth muscles that push lymph through lymphatic vessels via peristalsis. Therefore, smooth muscle contractions do in fact contribute to the circulation of lymph throughout the body. Option C. Skeletal muscle contractions – This option is incorrect. Recall that the lymphatic system does not have a central pump, like the heart. Instead of a central pump, the contraction of skeletal muscles will push lymph through the lymphatic vessels via the skeletal muscle pump. In addition, lymphatic vessels possess smooth muscles that push lymph through lymphatic vessels via peristalsis. Therefore, skeletal muscle contractions do in fact contribute to the circulation of lymph throughout the body. Option E. Lymphatic valves– This option is incorrect. Recall that the lymphatic system does not possess a central pump, like the heart. Therefore, the lymphatic system is a low-pressure system. Because of this, the lymphatic vessels possess valves that prevent the backflow of lymph. Because of this, lymphatic valves do in fact contribute to the circulation of lymph throughout the body.

question.text: Which of the following structures of a bird embryo is used to store uric acid and is later used for gas exchange?

explanation.concept_text: There are 4 primary extraembryonic membranes that you need to know for your test. Extraembryonic membranes are membranes that develop outside of the embryo proper in birds, reptiles, and mammals. The 4 extraembryonic membranes that you need to know are: the chorion , amnion , allantois , and yolk sac . This question asks about the allantois, so let’s focus our attention there. The allantois is a sac that buds off of the archenteron (a structure of the gastrula) that will eventually encircle the embryo and form the chorion. The allantois is a multifunctional membrane and has slightly different functions in egg-laying animals and placental animals. In egg-laying animals (like birds), the allantois is initially used to store uric acid but will later fuse with the chorion to form a membrane for gas exchange. In placental animals, the allantois will transport waste products to the placenta and develop into the umbilical cord later in development. The allantois will also become the urinary bladder in adults. Because the allantois initially stores uric acid and later fuses with the chorion for gas exchange in egg-laying animals (like birds), Option E . is the correct answer to this question. CC By 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Chorion – This option is incorrect .  The chorion is the outermost extraembryonic membrane. In egg-laying animals, the chorion will fuse with the allantois to form a membrane for gas exchange. In placental animals, the chorion will implant into the endometrium and will later fuse with the maternal tissue to form the placenta. Recall that the placenta is the tissue where gases, nutrients, and wastes are exchanged between the fetus and the mother. Option B. Yolk sac – This option is incorrect .  In egg-laying animals, the yolk sac provides nourishment to the developing embryo. In placental animals, the yolk sac is not as important for nourishing the embryo as the placenta is responsible for nourishment. In placental animals, the yolk sac is the first site of red blood cell synthesis. Option C. Amnion – This option is incorrect .  The amnion is the innermost extraembryonic membrane. The amnion contains amniotic fluid that functions to cushion and protect the developing embryo. It is important to note that amphibians to not possess an amnion. Option D. Placenta – This option is incorrect .  The placenta is an organ that develops during pregnancy in placental mammals. The placenta is a mix of paternal and embryonic tissue by which nutrients, gases, and wastes are exchanged between the fetus and mother. The umbilical cord is the structure that extends from the placenta and connects the placenta to the fetus.

question.text: Which of the following spends the majority of their lifecycle in the gametophyte generation?

explanation.concept_text: Recall that diploid (2n) cells are cells that contain two complete sets of chromosomes. In other words, diploid cells possess homologous chromosome pairs, 1 from the father and one from the mother. Humans are diploid organisms which means our somatic cells have two sets of chromosomes. In contrast, haploid (n) cells are cells that possess a single set of unpaired chromosomes. When diploid germ cells undergo meiosis, the daughter cells (gametes) are haploid. For this question, we need to understand a concept known as alternation of generations . Alternation of generations is a life cycle that’s observed in certain organisms like plants, fungi, and some protists. Alternation of generations is a process by which an organism will alternate between diploid (2n) and haploid (n) stages. While this process is a cycle, let’s begin in the sporophyte stage. Sporophytes are diploid and possess structures known as sporangia . When sporangia undergo meiosis, they produce haploid spores . These haploid spores will undergo mitosis to become a multicellular gametophyte that is still haploid (recall the spores that underwent mitosis to produce the gametophyte are haploid). The gametophyte is responsible for producing gametes which we should know are haploid. When two gametes fuse during fertilization, it produces a diploid zygote . This zygote will then undergo mitosis to become a multicellular diploid sporophyte. We’ve now finished the complete cycle! Bryophytes are non-vascular plants. Recall that vascular tissue consists of xylem and phloem. Examples of bryophytes include mosses, hornworts, and liverworts. Bryophytes spend the majority of their lifecycle in the gametophyte stage; therefore, Option A . is the correct answer to this question. CC By 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Ferns – This option is incorrect. Ferns are one of the examples of seedless tracheophytes (seedless vascular plants), therefore, ferns possess xylem and phloem. Ferns spend the majority of their lifecycle in the sporophyte stage, not the gametophyte stage. Option C. Pine trees – This option is incorrect. Pine trees are examples of conifers, which are gymnosperms. Gymnosperms are vascular plants whose seeds are not protected. Gymnosperms spend the majority of their lifecycle in the sporophyte stage, not the gametophyte stage. Option D. Sunflowers – This option is incorrect. Sunflowers are examples of angiosperms. Angiosperms are flower-bearing plants. Recall that the flower is the reproductive structure of the plant and it is composed of 3 primary components: the pistil, the stamen, and the pedals. Angiosperms spend the majority of their lifecycle in the sporophyte stage, not the gametophyte stage. Option E. Quillworts – This option is incorrect. Quillworts are examples of seedless tracheophytes (seedless vascular plants). Therefore, quillworts possess xylem and phloem but do not possess seeds. Quillworts spend the majority of their lifecycle in the sporophyte stage, not the gametophyte stage.

question.text: Which one of the following features are found in all members of Class Mammalia?

explanation.concept_text: Mammals , as the name suggests, are organisms that belong to the class Mammalia. For this question, we need to know that all mammals possess a diaphragm and in fact, the diaphragm is a structure exclusive to mammals. The diaphragm is a thin skeletal muscle that marks the lower border of the thoracic cavity. It is also important to note that the diaphragm is innervated by the phrenic nerve. Recall that inspiration is the intake of oxygen into the body which is required for aerobic cellular respiration. Inspiration is facilitated by the contraction of the diaphragm and the external intercostal muscles. Together, these muscles pull the lungs down and expand the thoracic cavity. Ultimately, this increases the volume in the lungs as well as decreases the intrapleural pressure, pulling air into the lungs. Once the air is in the lungs, the alveoli serve as the surface area of gas exchange between the respiratory system and the circulatory system. Once the oxygen has entered the circulatory system, blood will transport that oxygen throughout the body as required. CC By 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Fur – This option is incorrect. Fur is a natural layer of dense, thicker hair that’s found on the surface of many mammals. Fur primarily serves to provide insulation, camouflage, and protection. For this answer choice, it is important to note that not all mammals possess fur. For example, humans possess hair, which is a fine, thread-like structure that can be found in all areas of the body. While both hair and fur are made from keratin-based filaments, fur is a much thicker and denser layer than hair. While all mammals will possess hair or fur at some point in their lives, some species will shed this hair or fur later in development. Common examples of mammals that don’t keep their hair or fur are whales, dolphins, and porpoises who generally only have hair at birth. Option B. Feathers – This option is incorrect. The most well-known organisms that possess feathers are birds. Feathers have a few different functions. Some of these functions include insulation, flight, camouflage, and protection, among others. Mammals do not possess feathers. Option C. Sweat glands – This option is incorrect. Sweat glands, also known as sudoriferous glands, are glands in the skin that produce sweat. There are two different types of sweat glands: eccrine sweat glands and apocrine sweat glands. Eccrine sweat glands are the most abundant type of sweat glands, and they help with thermoregulation. Apocrine sweat glands are slightly bigger than eccrine sweat glands and are located in the arm pit, pubic region and nipples. The secretions from apocrine sweat glands are more viscous and are secreted into hair follicles. The function of apocrine secretions primarily depends on their location. While sweat glands are a common feature among many mammals, not all mammals possess sweat glands. Option E. Tail bone – This option is incorrect. The tail bone, also known as the coccyx, is a bone located at the base of the vertebral column in certain vertebrates. Many mammals possess a bony tail and therefore, have a tail bone, however, not all mammals have a tail bone. For example, whales and dolphins do not possess a tail bone. It is also worth noting that while humans possess a tail bone, it does not have a function and is therefore considered an evolutionary remnant, known as a vestigial structure.

question.text: Which of the following is NOT a function of the kidneys?

explanation.concept_text: The kidney is the most important organ of the excretory system. Kidneys are comprised of nephrons which are the functional unit of the kidney. Within the nephron, blood is filtered, minerals are secreted and reabsorbed, specialized cells monitor blood pressure, and wastes are excreted in the form of urine. Let’s briefly touch on each of these functions. The function of the nephron begins with the filtration of blood within the renal corpuscle, which is made up of the glomerulus and Bowman’s capsule. Within the renal corpuscle, water and small solutes like electrolytes and glucose will enter the filtrate whereas larger molecules like blood cells and proteins will remain in the circulation. Reabsorption is the process where substances will exit the filtrate and re-enter the circulation. Reabsorption begins in the proximal convoluted tubule and ends in the collecting duct. The most common substances that get reabsorbed in the nephron are water, glucose and amino acids, and electrolytes like sodium (NA + ), potassium (K + ), chloride (Cl - ), etc. Secretion is the opposite of reabsorption. Secretion is the movement of substances from the circulation into the filtrate of the nephron. Secretion primarily occurs in the proximal and distal convoluted tubules. The most common substances that are secreted in the nephron are potassium (K + ), hydrogen (H + ), and wastes that will enter the nephron for excretion. After reabsorption and secretion has occurred in the nephron, the filtrate will travel out of the collecting duct, at which point the filtrate is now known as urine. The urine will be sent through a ureter to the bladder where said urine is stored until excretion. Near the glomerulus are specialized cells, known as juxtaglomerular cells . These cells monitor blood pressure. If the juxtaglomerular cells detect that blood pressure is low, these cells will release renin which initiates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Ultimately, RAAS is responsible for the secretion of aldosterone from the adrenal cortex. Aldosterone is a hormone that will increase sodium (NA + ) and water reabsorption, as well as potassium (K + ) secretion in the distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct. The sodium and water reabsorption will lead to an increase in blood pressure. For this question, it is important to understand that nutrient absorption is the absorption of nutrients from the intestinal tract into circulation. Kidneys perform reabsorption, which is a different process. Reabsorption is the transportation of nutrients, often times electrolytes, from the filtrate of the nephron back into circulation. The absorption of nutrients does NOT occur in the kidneys; therefore Option E . is the correct answer to this question. CC By 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Excretion of wastes – This option is incorrect . One of the primary functions of the kidney, specifically the nephron, is the excretion of wastes in the form of urine. Option B. Mineral secretion – This option is incorrect . Recall that secretion is the movement of substances into the filtrate of the nephron from the circulation. Some of these substances include wastes, like creatinine, drugs, and toxins. Other substances that are secreted include minerals, like potassium (K + )! Option C. Filter blood – This option is incorrect . Recall that one of the functions of the nephron is the filtration of blood. The renal corpuscle, which is made up of the glomerulus and the Bowman’s capsule, will filter blood by allowing water and small solutes into the filtrate, while preventing larger molecules like proteins and blood cells from entering. Option D. Monitor blood pressure – This option is incorrect . Recall that specialized cells near the glomerulus, known as juxtaglomerular cells, monitor blood pressure and release renin when blood pressure is low. This initiates that renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) which will ultimately end in the release of aldosterone from the adrenal cortex when blood pressure is low. Aldosterone will result in the reabsorption of sodium (Na + ) and water, as well as the secretion of potassium (K + ) in the distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct. The reabsorption of sodium (Na + ) and water will lead to an increase in blood pressure.

question.text: Which of the following structures produce epinephrine?

explanation.concept_text: The adrenal medulla , the inner layer of the adrenal gland, is responsible for the production of catecholamines including epinephrine and norepinephrine (also known as adrenaline and noradrenaline). Therefore, Option B. Adrenal medulla , is the correct answer. This concept is illustrated in the image below. Epinephrine and norepinephrine are involved in the sympathetic nervous response. Recall that the sympathetic nervous system is involved in the fight or flight response. Some of the physiological processes that occur during the fight or flight response include an increase in heart rate, dilation of the pupils, increased respiration, constriction of blood flow to the skin, mucus membranes, and kidney, dilation of blood flow to the heart, lungs, and skeletal muscles, etc. CC By 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Pineal gland – This option is incorrect .  The pineal gland is responsible for the production of melatonin. Melatonin is an amino acid-derived hormone that regulates the body’s circadian rhythm. The pineal gland does not produce epinephrine. Option C. Anterior pituitary – This option is incorrect .  The anterior pituitary is one of the two lobes that make up the pituitary gland. The anterior pituitary is responsible for the production and secretion of many hormones. Some of these hormones include thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), prolactin, etc. The anterior pituitary is not responsible for the production of epinephrine. Option D. Posterior pituitary – This option is incorrect .  The posterior pituitary is one of the two lobes that make up the pituitary gland. The posterior pituitary is continuous with the hypothalamus, and therefore, doesn’t actually produce its own hormones. Instead, the hypothalamus produces antidiuretic hormone (ADH) and oxytocin which the posterior pituitary is responsible for secreting. The posterior pituitary does not produce epinephrine. Option E. Adrenal cortex – This option is incorrect .  The adrenal cortex is superficial to the adrenal medulla in the adrenal gland. The adrenal cortex is responsible for the production of glucocorticoids, like cortisol, as well as mineralocorticoids, like aldosterone. The adrenal cortex does not produce epinephrine.

question.text: Natural selection, as proposed by Charles Darwin, is best described by which of the following?

options.label: A.
options.text: Genetic variation occurs as a result of random changes in a gene

options.label: B.
options.text: Certain traits become heritable as a result of greater usage of that trait

options.label: C.
options.text: Heritable alleles that promote fitness are passed to offspring

options.label: D.
options.text: Deliberate selection of desirable traits in a species by humans

options.label: E.
options.text: Intermediate traits are favored in a population

correct_answer_text: Heritable alleles that promote fitness are passed to offspring

explanation.concept_text: Natural selection is an evolutionary term coined by Charles Darwin. Natural selection describes the non-random increase or decrease in allele frequencies in order to adapt to the environment. You may recognize the term “survival of the fittest” which is in direct relation to natural selection. Recall that fitness describes an organism’s ability to survive and produce viable offspring. In essence, the organisms that possess the most fit alleles (alleles that increase the chances of survival) will be able to survive and pass on those alleles to their offspring. Over time, these alleles become more prevalent within a population and the less fit alleles are filtered out. It is also important to note that there are three primary forms of natural selection: stabilizing selection , disruptive selection , and directional selection . Because natural selection describes a process by which heritable alleles that increase fitness are passed on to offspring, Option C . is the correct answer to this question.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Genetic variation occurs as a result of random changes in a gene – This option is incorrect .  Recall that natural selection is a non-random process by which alleles that increase the chances of survival are passed on to offspring and increase in frequency within a population. Natural selection is not a result of random changes in a gene, or mutations. Option B. Certain traits become heritable as a result of greater usage of that trait – This option is incorrect .  Recall that Lamarck’s theory of use and disuse proposed that body parts which were used more frequently would develop more while body parts that are not used frequently will atrophy away. Lamarck also proposed his theory of inheritance of acquired traits whereby traits that are acquired during one’s life will be passed to offspring. These theories have been disproven and it also does not describe the theory of natural selection which was proposed by Charles Darwin. Option D. Deliberate selection of desirable traits in a species by humans – This option is incorrect .  Artificial selection is a type of selection performed by humans by which desirable traits are selected and bred for. Artificial selection is commonly seen in dogs. Dogs with favorable traits are bred so those favorable traits can be passed to their offspring. Option E. Intermediate traits are favored in a population – This option is incorrect .  This option is describing stabilizing selection, which is one of the three primary types of natural selection. When a species undergoes stabilizing selection, traits at each end of the extreme are selected against and the intermediate traits are favored. While stabilizing selection is a type of natural selection, it does not describe the fundamentals of natural selection as a whole, which is what this question requires.

question.text: A zoologist travels to different biome communities, keeping track of how many members of different species she encounters. For example, in a forest community, she notes that there are 50 bears, 20 squirrels, and 10 beavers so she writes Forest: 50, 20, 10. She does this for several more biomes. Which biome community demonstrates the most species diversity?

explanation.concept_text: Let us first define some basic terms. A population is the collection of all members of the same species that live in a certain area. A community is the broader collection of all of the populations found in an area. Biological diversity or biodiversity describes both the richness and evenness of a community. The richness of a community describes the number of different species present without regard for their population count. The evenness of a community describes the relative population size of each species in a community. For example, consider a community with 1000 species A and 2000 species B, and another community with 1500 species A and 1500 species B. The two communities have the same richness because they both have 2 different species. However, the second community exhibits greater evenness because both species are present in 50% abundance in contrast to the 33% and 66% distribution found in the first community. First, we can examine the question choices on the basis of richness. We can say that communities C and D are the  richest because they both have 5 different species. Second, we can examine the question choices on the basis of evenness. We can say that communities A and D are the most even since the relative abundance of all present species is the same within these communities. Finally, we find that the community that exhibits both high richness and evenness will have the highest diversity among all of the other communities. From the given option choices, Community D exhibits both high richness and evenness. Therefore, Option D . Desert: 20, 20, 20, 20, 20 , is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Grassland: 50, 50 – This option is incorrect .  Having only 2 species, this community is the least rich among the answer choices. Recall that both richness and evenness contribute to biodiversity. Because this option is the least rich, it is also the least diverse. Option B. Tundra: 90, 7, 3, 1 – This option is incorrect .  This community only has 4 different species. Both Option C. and Option D. have 5 species within their communities, making have richer than the tundra biome. Because richness and evenness contribute to biodiversity, this option is not the most diverse. Option C. Forest: 40, 30, 15, 10, 5 – This option is incorrect .  Similar to Option D, the community has 5 difference species. This means that the forest has the same richness as the desert, however, the population size of the desert is even with each species having a population size of 20. The species within the forest have uneven population sizes. Recall that richness AND evenness contribute to biodiversity. Since the desert has greater evenness than the forest, this option is incorrect. Option E. Aquatic: 50, 30, 20 – This option is incorrect .  This community only has 3 species, making it less rich than both Option C. and Option D. Recall that richness and evenness contribute to biodiversity. Since this option is less rich than Option D. this answer choice is incorrect.

question.text: A student is running late for their exam and sprints across campus. During this short period of intense exercise, decreased _________ availability leads to increased production of _________.

explanation.concept_text: For this question, we need to understand that short bursts of intense exercise are forms of anaerobic exercise . Recall that when oxygen is present, humans will undergo aerobic cellular respiration in order to produce ATP, which is the energy currency of the cell. However, when oxygen is absent (or is not present in sufficient amounts for the needs of the cell, which can occur during intense exercise), humans are not able to utilize aerobic cellular respiration. Recall that during aerobic respiration, oxygen is the final electron acceptor. If oxygen is absent, humans will have to produce ATP anaerobically. In order to do this, they will utilize fermentation and glycolysis . Recall that glycolysis is the first step of aerobic cellular respiration. During glycolysis, a glucose molecule is broken down into two pyruvate molecules. During the process, two NAD + are oxidized into NADH. In addition, a net of two ATP is produced. The final yield resulting from glycolysis with the use of one glucose molecule is two pyruvate , two NADH , and two ATP . It’s very important to remember that glycolysis can only proceed if NAD + is present. It turns out that NAD + is also required for the next two steps of aerobic respiration to proceed: pyruvate decarboxylation and the Krebs cycle, respectively. NAD + gets regenerated during the final step of aerobic respiration, known as the oxidative phosphorylation. We won’t get into the details of oxidative phosphorylation for this solution but just know that NADH and FADH 2 are oxidized into NAD + and FAD. This is how NAD + gets regenerated so it can be used again during the pyruvate decarboxylation step and the Krebs cycle. However, oxygen is the final electron acceptor during oxidative phosphorylation, so oxidative phosphorylation can only proceed if oxygen is available. This is why oxidative phosphorylation directly relies on oxygen and the pyruvate decarboxylation step and the Krebs cycle indirectly rely on oxygen. So, if NAD + is required for glycolysis to proceed, where does glycolysis get it from? The answer to that question is fermentation . Fermentation is a completely anaerobic process and resupplies glycolysis with NAD + so glycolysis can continue to produce ATP in the absence of oxygen. There are two types of fermentation that you need to know for your test: lactic acid fermentation and alcohol fermentation . Humans undergo lactic acid fermentation whereby the pyruvate that’s produced from glycolysis will not undergo the pyruvate decarboxylation step, but instead, will enter the fermentation pathway. From here, the pyruvate will be converted into lactate while NADH is oxidized into NAD + . This NAD + can be used to continue glycolysis. An image outlining lactic acid fermentation can be found below. If a student were to spring across campus in a short bit of intense exercise, that student would be placed under brief anaerobic conditions, resulting from a lack of available oxygen. This would cause that student to undergo glycolysis and lactic acid fermentation for their energy requirements. Recall that lactic acid fermentation is the conversion of pyruvate into lactate within the myocyte (muscle cell). Because of this, Option A. is the correct answer to this question. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. O 2 , ethanol – This option is incorrect. While it is true that sprinting leads to a decrease in the availability of oxygen (O 2 ), humans undergo lactic acid fermentation. Lactic acid fermentation is the conversion of pyruvate into lactate. Alcohol fermentation, on the other hand, is the conversion of pyruvate into acetaldehyde and then ethanol. Yeast undergo alcohol fermentation. Humans undergo lactic acid fermentation, and therefore, would not produce ethanol. Option C. CO 2 , lactate – This option is incorrect. Sprinting across campus would result in a decrease in the availability of oxygen (O 2 ), not carbon dioxide (CO 2 ). Because oxygen is not available (or less available), humans will undergo glycolysis and lactic acid fermentation. Lactic acid fermentation is the conversion of pyruvate into lactate, therefore, there would be an increase in the production of lactate. Option D. Lactate, insulin– This option is incorrect. Sprinting across campus would result in a decrease in the amount of oxygen (O 2 ) that’s available. This would lead humans to undergo glycolysis and lactic acid fermentation during this brief anaerobic period. Lactic acid fermentation is the conversion of pyruvate into lactate, therefore, there would be an increase, not a decrease in lactate. Insulin is a hormone that decreases blood glucose levels. Insulin does not play a role in the metabolic processes being tested in this question. Option E. Ethanol, glucagon – This option is incorrect. Sprinting across campus would result in a decrease in the amount of oxygen (O 2 ) that’s available. This would lead humans to undergo glycolysis and lactic acid fermentation during this brief anaerobic period. Lactic acid fermentation is the conversion of pyruvate into lactate. Alcohol fermentation is the other form of fermentation performed by yeast, not humans. Alcohol fermentation is the conversion of pyruvate into acetaldehyde and then ethanol. Humans would NOT produce ethanol. Additionally, glucagon is a hormone that plays a role in the increase of blood glucose levels. Glucagon does not play a role in the metabolic processes being tested in this question.

question.text: What statement describes conditions in which two populations of the same species of organism live in the same geographic area and undergo speciation without a geographical barrier present?

explanation.concept_text: Allopatric speciation is the formation of new species, speciation , due to reproductive isolation resulting from a geographic barrier. This geographic barrier separates a population and interrupts gene flow. As a result, the gene pool diverges enough that reproduction between the separated population is no longer possible because the gametes are no longer compatible. Due to the lack of breeding between the separated populations and the evolution of each population to their respective environment, new species will be formed. In contrast, sympatric speciation is a speciation event that occurs without geographic barriers. Instead, reproductive isolation occurs by other mechanisms (balanced polymorphism, polyploidy, and hybridization). The image below illustrates this concept. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Allopatric speciation – This option is incorrect . Recall that allopatric speciation is a speciation event that occurs with the presence of a geographic barrier, like a river or mountain range. Sympatric speciation is a speciation event that occurs without the presence of a geographical barrier. Option C. Directional speciation – This option is incorrect . Directional speciation is not a legitimate evolutionary term; however, directional selection is. Recall that directional selection is a type of natural selection by which traits at one end of the extreme are favored. For example, let’s say within a given population, the babies were all born very small. Over time, the population saw a decrease in very small babies being born and a very large increase in large babies being born. This is an example of directional selection but once again, directional speciation is not a legitimate evolutionary term. Option D. Homologous speciation – This option is incorrect . Homologous speciation is not a recognized evolutionary term, however, evolution can result in homologous structures. Homologous structures are structures on two different species that may or may not perform the same function but were derived from a common ancestor. One of the most common examples of a homologous structure is the forearm of a human and the wing of a bird.

question.text: The first living organisms to appear on Earth were __________.

explanation.concept_text: For this question, we need to remember the difference between prokaryotes and eukaryotes . Prokaryotes are cells that lack membrane-bound organelles, whereas eukaryotes possess membrane-bound organelles (such as a nucleus). Prokaryotes undergo much simpler processes than eukaryotes and therefore, would have arisen before eukaryotic cells. We also need to understand the difference between heterotrophs and autotrophs . Heterotrophs are organisms that are not capable of producing their own food and therefore, intake nutrients from the surroundings like plant and animal matter. Autotrophs, on the other hand, are organisms that are capable of producing their own organic substances from inorganic substances. The most common autotrophic process is photosynthesis whereby photons from the sun are utilized to convert carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) and water (H 2 O) into organic glucose with the release of atmospheric oxygen as a byproduct. While the complexity of autotrophs and heterotrophs varies greatly, it is most likely that the very first organisms on earth were heterotrophic, utilizing the available carbon sources from their environment. In summary, the most primordial organisms are going to undergo the simplest processes. Therefore, the first organisms on earth were heterotrophic prokaryotes. Because of this, Option B. is the correct answer to this question.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Autotrophic eukaryotes – This option is incorrect. Recall that eukaryotes possess membrane-bound organelles, unlike prokaryotes. Because of this, prokaryotes are simpler organisms than eukaryotes. Additionally, heterotrophs are organisms that cannot produce their own food. Autotrophs, on the other hand, are able to produce their own food. It is likely that the first organisms on earth were heterotrophic, utilizing the organic carbon that was available from their environment. In summary, heterotrophic prokaryotes are simpler than autotrophic eukaryotes. The most primordial organisms on earth are also going to be the simplest organisms, therefore, heterotrophic prokaryotes would be the first organisms on earth. Option C. Unicellular eukaryotes – This option is incorrect. Unicellular eukaryotes are known as protists. Recall that eukaryotes possess membrane-bound organelles whereas prokaryotes do not. This makes eukaryotes more complex than prokaryotes. The most primordial organisms would be the simplest organisms. Therefore, this very first organisms would’ve been prokaryotes and not eukaryotes. Option D. Photosynthetic prokaryotes – This option is incorrect. Photosynthesis is a complex autotrophic process whereby photons from the sun are used to convert carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) and water (H 2 O) into glucose with the release of atmospheric oxygen as a byproduct. Recall that the first organisms to utilize photosynthesis were cyanobacteria, however, cyanobacteria were not the first organisms on earth. Option E. Autotrophic archaea – This option is incorrect. Heterotrophs are organisms that cannot produce their own food. Autotrophs, on the other hand, are able to produce their own food. The most common autotrophic process is photosynthesis which is the utilization of photons from the sun to convert carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) and water (H 2 O) into glucose with the release of atmospheric oxygen (O 2 ) as a byproduct. Recall that both archaea and bacteria are prokaryotic organisms and therefore, lack membrane-bound organelles. For this answer choice, we need to know that the first organism on earth was likely heterotrophic that intakes organic substances from its surroundings.

question.text: Which of the following is the primary feedback regulatory mechanism of the hypothalamus to maintain homeostasis?

explanation.concept_text: For this question, we need to understand feedback loops . When discussing feedback loops for the biology section, it is usually in reference to the endocrine system. Feedback loops are regulatory mechanisms whereby the release of a particular hormone will signal for the inhibition of a particular endocrine tissue ( negative feedback ) or the amplification of a particular endocrine tissue ( positive feedback ). Recall that the hypothalamus is a tissue of the brain that responsible for the production of a variety of hormones, some of which are corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH), thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH), gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH), somatostatin, antidiuretic hormone (ADH), and oxytocin. The hypothalamus is involved in both positive and negative feedback loops, however, the primary regulatory mechanism of the hypothalamus involved negative feedback loops. One such example of a negative feedback loop involving the hypothalamus is the secretion of thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3) via the hypothalamic-pituitary-thyroid axis. This negative feedback cycle begins with the secretion of thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) from the hypothalamus. TRH will signal the release of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) from the anterior pituitary. Thyroid-stimulating hormone will then signal the release of both thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3) from the thyroid gland. Once T4 and T3 have been released, the body will detect this and cause a negative feedback loop on the hypothalamus, inhibiting the releasing of thyrotropin-releasing hormone. This will also inhibit the continued secretion of thyroid-stimulating hormone from the anterior pituitary and therefore, the thyroid gland will stop secreting thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3). This negative feedback loop helps maintain homeostasis and prevents the over secretion of a particular hormone(s). An image depicting the hypothalamic-pituitary-thyroid axis is shown below. One example of a positive feedback loop involving the hypothalamus is observed during the female menstrual cycle. Recall that ovulation is a result of a spike in luteinizing hormone (LH) from the anterior pituitary. This spike in LH is a result of a positive feedback loop! During the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle, estrogen levels continuously rise. Once the estrogen levels reach a certain threshold, it will cause a positive feedback loop on the hypothalamus, ultimately causing the hypothalamus to secrete gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) This GnRH will lead to a surge in luteinizing hormone (LH) from the anterior pituitary, ultimately causing ovulation! It should be noted that positive feedback loops do NOT return an organism to homeostasis but instead, push an organism even further beyond homeostasis. While the hypothalamus is involved in both positive and negative feedback loops, negative feedback loops are much more common and are the primary regulatory mechanism of the hypothalamus used to maintain homeostasis. Therefore, Option A . is the correct answer to this question. CC By 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Positive Feedback – This option is incorrect .  Recall that the hypothalamus is involved in both negative and positive feedback loops. Negative feedback loops will help return an organism to homeostasis whereas positive feedback loops will push an organism beyond homeostasis. Additionally, positive feedback loops are much rarer for the hypothalamus than negative feedback loops. Negative feedback loops are the primary regulatory mechanism of the hypothalamus that helps maintain homeostasis. Option C. Cell Cycle Checkpoint – This option is incorrect .  Cell cycle checkpoints are involved in cell division. Recall that there are three cell cycle checkpoints that you should know for your test. The first checkpoint occurs at the end of gap phase 1 (G1). The second checkpoint occurs at the end of gap phase 2 (G2). The third checkpoint occurs during metaphase. These checkpoints ensure that cell division occurs properly. The cell cycle checkpoints have nothing to do with feedback loops or maintaining homeostasis on a system level. Option D. Secondary Messenger Cascade – This option is incorrect .  Recall that secondary messengers are molecules that transmit signals from the surface of the cell to the inside of the cell. Secondary messengers are often used to transmit a signal from a peptide hormone to inside of the cell. Recall that peptide hormones are water-soluble and therefore, cannot freely diffuse across the membrane of the cell. Because of this, peptide hormones must utilize secondary messengers in order to relay their message to the intracellular environment. The secondary messengers that you need to know for your test are cyclic AMP (cAMP), inositol triphosphate (IP3), diacylglycerol (DAG), and calcium ions. While the hypothalamus does produce and secrete lipid-insoluble hormones, secondary messenger cascades do not regulate the hypothalamus. They simply transmit a signal from outside of a target cell to the inside of that cell. Option E. Suppressor Gene – This option is incorrect .  Suppressor genes are genes that regulate cell division and prevent the development of cancer. Some common examples of suppressor genes are p53, p21, and retinoblastoma gene. Suppressor genes are not directly involved with the function of the hypothalamus.

question.text: Oxygen is critical for aerobic cellular respiration because __________.

options.label: B.
options.text: Glycolysis could not function without oxygen

options.label: C.
options.text: Oxygen is the final electron acceptor

options.label: D.
options.text: The breakdown of water requires oxygen

correct_answer_text: Oxygen is the final electron acceptor

explanation.concept_text: Oxygen (O 2 ) is the final electron acceptor in the process of aerobic cellular respiration. Recall that aerobic cellular respiration is the primary metabolic process that aerobic organisms utilize to produce ATP, which is the energy currency of the cell. As the name suggests, aerobic cellular respiration requires oxygen to proceed. Aerobic respiration can be broken down into 4 primary stages: Oxidative phosphorylation , as we can see, is the final stage of aerobic respiration. Oxidative phosphorylation involves an electron transport chain as well as the phosphorylation of ADP into ATP via chemiosmosis . During oxidative phosphorylation, the electron transport chain (found in the inner mitochondrial membrane of eukaryotes and the cell membrane of prokaryotes) will oxidize NADH and FADH 2 into NAD + and FAD. At this point, it is important to mention that protein complex I will oxidize NADH and protein complex II will oxidize FADH 2 . The electrons that are released from the oxidation of NADH and FADH 2 will be passed down the electron transport chain which consists of 4 protein complexes. As the electrons are being passed from one complex to the next, the energy that’s released is used to pump protons from the mitochondrial matrix into the intermembrane space. This creates an electrochemical gradient which is important for chemiosmosis. Once the protons have been pumped into the intermembrane space, they will be pumped through ATP synthase back into the mitochondrial matrix. This pumping of protons through ATP synthase will phosphorylate ADP into ATP via chemiosmosis. For this question, it is crucial to understand that oxygen acts as the final electron acceptor for oxidative phosphorylation. Oxygen will combine with electrons and protons to form water (H 2 O) which is the reason that oxidative phosphorylation DIRECTLY depends on oxygen. As we see, oxidative phosphorylation is responsible for the production of ATP and water as well as the oxidation of NADH and FADH 2 into NAD + and FAD. This oxidation is important because the pyruvate decarboxylation step and the Krebs cycle rely on NAD + to proceed. Oxidative phosphorylation is responsible for replenishing the NAD + stores that are used in pyruvate decarboxylation and the Krebs cycle. In this way, pyruvate decarboxylation and the Krebs cycle INDIRECTLY rely on oxygen. It should be noted that oxidative phosphorylation replenishes NAD + for glycolysis when oxygen is available, however, fermentation will replenish NAD + when oxygen is not available. Ultimately, without the presence of oxygen, aerobic respiration cannot proceed. Without aerobic respiration, aerobic organisms are not capable of surviving and will die off as a result. CC By 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. All living organisms require oxygen – This option is incorrect. Earth has a tremendous amount of biodiversity with many organisms utilizing different metabolic processes. For example, facultative anaerobes, obligate aerobes, and microaerophiles utilize oxygen for their metabolic needs; however, obligate anaerobes and aerotolerant organisms do NOT use oxygen for their energy needs. These organisms will either utilize anaerobic respiration or fermentation for their metabolic requirements. Option B. Glycolysis could not function without oxygen – This option is incorrect. Recall that glycolysis is the metabolic process by which a glucose molecule is broken down to yield a net of 2 pyruvate, 2 ATP, and 2 NADH. Glycolysis is the first step of cellular respiration and is a completely anaerobic process. This is because the NAD + that’s required for glycolysis to proceed can be resupplied via fermentation, an anaerobic process. In this way, glycolysis does not indirectly rely on oxidative phosphorylation (an aerobic process) to resupply NAD + ; therefore, glycolysis does NOT require oxygen. Option D. The breakdown of water requires oxygen – This option is incorrect. Recall that the photolysis of water is the first step of the light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis. During the photolysis of water, photons from the sun will break down a water molecule into 2 protons (H + ), 2 electrons (e - ), and ½ atmospheric oxygen (O 2 ). This process does NOT occur during aerobic cellular respiration. During aerobic cellular respiration, oxygen acts as the final electron acceptor. Once the electrons have been passed along the electron transport chain during the oxidative phosphorylation step, those electrons (along with protons) will join oxygen (O 2 ) to become water. Because the breakdown of water does NOT occur during aerobic cellular respiration, this option is incorrect. Option E. Oxygen is required for fermentation – This option is incorrect. Recall that glycolysis requires NAD + in order to proceed. Under aerobic conditions (when oxygen is present), oxidative phosphorylation will regenerate the NAD + that’s required for pyruvate decarboxylation, the Krebs cycle, and glycolysis. However, under anaerobic conditions (when oxygen is not present), the pyruvate that’s produced from glycolysis will NOT go on to be decarboxylated but will instead, enter the fermentation pathway. There are two forms of fermentation, lactic acid fermentation and alcohol fermentation. Both types of fermentation will oxidize NADH into NAD + which can directly be used for glycolysis to continue making small amounts of ATP while oxygen is not available. It is crucial to remember that fermentation does NOT require oxygen.

question.text: What is the primary use of Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)?

options.label: A.
options.text: Detect specific DNA strands in a sample

options.label: B.
options.text: Study protein activity and motion through a cell

options.label: C.
options.text: Create copies of a DNA sequence

correct_answer_text: Create copies of a DNA sequence

explanation.concept_text: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is an automated molecular biology technique used to make millions of copies of a specified region of DNA. PCR utilizes DNA primers, Taq polymerase (a heat-resistant DNA polymerase), a thermal cycler, and a sample of the DNA that the researcher wishes to be amplified. The protocol for PCR requires the researcher to place the DNA sample, Taq polymerase, and DNA primers into a PCR tube. Once in the tube, the researcher will place the tube into the thermal cycler which, as the name suggests, will cycle through three different temperatures which can be associated with the three stages of the polymerase chain reaction: denaturation (~95° C), primer annealing (~65° C), and elongation (~70° C). Each cycle of denaturation, primer annealing, and elongation, the amount of double-stranded DNA segments will double. Therefore, after n cycles of PCR, the yield of DNA will be 2n copies. The first step of PCR is denaturation by which the heat from the thermal cycler will physically separate the DNA double helix into two single strands. The next step of PCR is primer annealing. Primer annealing is the hybridization of the forward and reverses primer to define the exact region of DNA to be replicated. The final step of PCR is elongation by which the Taq polymerase will add nucleotides to the 3’ end of each single-stranded DNA sequence. This finalizes one cycle of PCR. The sole purpose of PCR is to replicate a specified DNA sequence for study; therefore, Option A. DNA replication is the correct answer. CC By 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Detect specific DNA strands in a sample – This option is incorrect. Southern blotting is a molecular biological technique by which specific DNA segments can be detected within a sample of DNA. During a southern blot, the DNA is first ‘cut’ with restriction enzymes, resulting in smaller DNA fragments. These fragments can then be separated using gel electrophoresis. After being electrophoresed, the DNA fragments are then denatured (separated into single strands) and transferred to a membrane (much like during a western blot). After the transfer, the membrane will be exposed to a ‘DNA probe’ which is a sequence of single-stranded DNA that will hybridize to its complementary strand. The membrane is then image and the hybridized probe will be detected. This offers scientists an idea about the presence and size of the DNA segment of interest within the sample. Southern blotting is a separate biological technique from polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Option B. Study protein activity and motion through a cell – This option is incorrect. Pulse-chase experiments are used to how proteins move throughout the cell. During a pulse-chase experiment, radioactive, or fluorescent amino acids are briefly introduced into a solution in which a cell resides. That cell will take up these labelled amino acids to incorporate into their proteins, representing the pulse of radioactivity or fluorescence. Subsequent unlabeled amino acids are introduced as the chase. The motion of the labelled proteins would visually resemble a pulse as it moves around the cell which allows them to be tracked.  PCR is used at the nucleic acid level, not the protein level. Option D. Sequence genomes – This option is incorrect. Genome sequencing is a process that’s used to determine the complete DNA sequence of a particular organism’s genome. The two major forms of genome sequencing that you should know for your test are Sanger Sequencing and Next-Generation sequencing. Polymerase chain reaction is used to amplify a segment of DNA but it is not used to sequence a genome. Option E. Observe chromosomes during metaphase – This option is incorrect. The observation of chromosomes during metaphase describes a microscopic technique known as karyotyping. In metaphase, the chromosomes are condensed and lined up in the center of the cell. This makes them easily studied often for diagnostics purposes. A count of chromosomes can enable an operator to identify various chromosomal conditions, including aneuploidies.  Polymerase chain reaction involves the amplification of a segment of DNA, not the observation of chromosomes during metaphase.

question.text: What is the indicated organelle and its function?

explanation.concept_text: The Golgi apparatus is an organelle found in eukaryotic cells. The Golgi apparatus is characterized by flattened sacs, known as cisternae (as seen in the image in question). Once proteins have been synthesized in the rough endoplasmic reticulum, those proteins will enter the Golgi apparatus at the cis face (which faces the ER). Once in the Golgi, said proteins will be modified and packages based upon their destination (cell membrane, exocytosis, or some other area within the cell). One of the most common protein modifications is glycosylation, whereby a carbohydrate is added to the protein in order to convert that protein into a glycoprotein. Once the proteins have been modified and packaged, they will exit the Golgi at the trans face (which faces the plasma membrane) and travel to their destination. It is also important to note that the Golgi is involved in the synthesis of lysosomes, which are membrane-bound organelles that contain digestive enzymes that break down certain substances within the cell. For this question, it is crucial to be able to recognize certain organelles on an electron micrograph. The Golgi’s cisternae are the distinguishing feature that help us identify this organelle, therefore, Option E . is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Lysosomes –Break down of substances – This option is incorrect . Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles that contain digestive enzymes which function at low pH in order to break down certain substances within the cell. Recall that the Golgi apparatus is characterized by flattened sacs, known as cisternae. These flattened sacs can clearly be visualized in the image in question, therefore, the organelle in question is the Golgi apparatus, not a lysosome. Option B. Nucleus – DNA storage – This option is incorrect . The nucleus is a double membrane-bound organelle that stores genetic material in the form of chromatin (or chromosomes when the cell is undergoing replication). The nucleus is also the site of DNA transcription, which is the conversion of DNA into messenger RNA (mRNA). The nucleolus (found within the nucleus) would be easily visible in an electron micrograph as a dark spot within the nucleus. Recall that the nucleolus is the site of ribosomal RNA (rRNA) synthesis. In the image in question, it is clear that the flattened sacs are representing the cisternae that are found in the Golgi apparatus. Therefore, this option is incorrect. Option C. Rough endoplasmic reticulum – Protein Synthesis – This option is incorrect . Recall that the rough endoplasmic reticulum is studded with ribosomes, which is a distinguishing feature of rough ER. Ribosomes would appear as small black dots on the surface of the rough ER in an electron micrograph. Because the rough ER is studded with ribosomes, we know that the rough ER is involved in protein synthesis. However, despite the function and organelle being correctly paired, the image in question is depicting the Golgi apparatus - not the rough ER. Option D. Mitochondria – ATP Production – This option is incorrect . Mitochondria are double membrane-bound organelles that are responsible for the production of ATP within the cell. This is why mitochondria are known as the powerhouse of the cell! Mitochondria possess inner folds, known as cristae. On an electron micrograph, these cristae appear similar to the cisternae of the Golgi, however, the mitochondria possesses and outer and inner membrane whereas the Golgi only possesses one membrane.

question.text: What hormones produce female secondary sex characteristics?

explanation.concept_text: Secondary sex characteristics are characteristics that develop during puberty which help differentiate males and females apart from their primary reproductive organs. Some of the main female sex characteristics include: the development of breasts, widening of the hips, pubic hair growth, and menstruation. The development of the female sex characteristics occurs as a result of estrogen (the primary hormone responsible for the development of female sex characteristics) and progesterone , which has a slightly more indirect role than estrogen. Recall that estrogen and progesterone are secreted from the ovaries. Because estrogen and progesterone are responsible for the development of female sex characteristics, Option E. is the correct answer to this question.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Progesterone and FSH – This option is incorrect . While progesterone is responsible for the development of female secondary sex characteristics, follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) is not directly involved. Recall that follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) is secreted from the anterior pituitary gland and is responsible for the development of follicles in the ovary. Those developing follicles will then secrete estrogen which IS responsible for the development of secondary sex characteristics. It is important to remember that progesterone and estrogen will lead to the development of secondary sex characteristics, therefore, this option is incorrect. Option B. LH and  Estrogen – This option is incorrect . Recall that estrogen is the primary hormone that leads to the development of female sex characteristics, however, luteinizing hormone (LH) is primarily involved in ovulation. Recall that a spike in LH (secreted from the anterior pituitary) leads to the release of an egg from the Graafian follicle around day 14 of the menstrual cycle. It is important to remember that progesterone and estrogen will lead to the development of secondary sex characteristics, therefore, this option is incorrect. Option C. LH and  Progesterone – This option is incorrect . Recall that progesterone is involved in the development of female secondary sex characteristics, however, luteinizing hormone (LH) is not. Recall that a spike in LH (secreted from the anterior pituitary) leads to the release of an egg from the Graafian follicle around day 14 of the menstrual cycle. It is important to remember that progesterone and estrogen will lead to the development of secondary sex characteristics, therefore, this option is incorrect. Option D. FSH and  hCG – This option is incorrect . Follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) is secreted from the anterior pituitary and leads to the development of follicles during the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle. FSH doesn’t directly affect the development of female secondary sex characteristics. Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCH) is secreted from the placenta after implantation of the blastocyst into the uterine wall. hCG is responsible for maintaining the corpus luteum, which continuously secretes estrogen and progesterone to maintain the thickness of the endometrium after implantation has occurred. hCG is not involved in the development of female secondary sex characteristics. It is important to remember that progesterone and estrogen will lead to the development of secondary sex characteristics, therefore, this option is incorrect.

question.text: All of the following are true of mitochondria EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

options.label: A.
options.text: They have their own unique DNA

explanation.concept_text: Mitochondria are double membrane-bound organelles that are responsible for the production of ATP (the energy currency of the cell). This is the reason that mitochondria are considered the powerhouse of the cell. Recall that the mitochondrion is the site of aerobic cellular respiration and beta-oxidation (fatty acid oxidation), both of which produce lots of ATP! It is also important to note that mitochondria possess their own DNA, exclusive to the DNA found in the nucleus. It should also be known that the mitochondrial DNA is always inherited from the mother . Mitochondria also possess ribosomes , which are the organelles responsible for arranging amino acids in the correct sequence during protein translation. Glycolysis is the first step of cellular respiration and is completely anaerobic. During glycolysis, a molecule of glucose gets broken down to yield a net of 2 pyruvate, 2 NADH, and 2 ATP. It is important to remember that glycolysis occurs in the cytosol, outside of the mitochondria. Once glycolysis is complete, the pyruvate gets shuttled into the mitochondria to complete the remaining steps of aerobic cellular respiration. If oxygen is not present, the pyruvate produced from glycolysis will instead enter the fermentation pathway. Because the mitochondrion is not the site of glycolysis, Option C. is the correct answer to this question. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. They have their own unique DNA – This option is incorrect . Mitochondria possess their own DNA which is exclusive to the chromosomal DNA found in the nucleus. It is also important to note that mitochondrial DNA is inherited from the mother. Paternal DNA is NOT found within mitochondria. Because this option is a true statement about mitochondria, this option is incorrect. Option B. Muscle cells contain many mitochondria – This option is incorrect . Muscles are highly energy dependent. Muscles are responsible for movement of the body and require a lot of ATP to perform their function. Because of this, mitochondria are integral organelles found within muscle cells. Option D. Contain ribosomes – This option is incorrect . Recall that ribosomes are the organelles that are responsible for the translation of messenger RNA (mRNA) into a protein. Mitochondria do indeed possess ribosomes, which are distinct from the ribosomes found in the cytoplasm of the cell. Option E . Have a double membrane – This option is incorrect . Mitochondria are double membrane-bound organelle that’s found in eukaryotic cells. The two membranes that mitochondria possess are the outer membrane and the inner membrane. Because mitochondria do indeed possess two membranes, this option is incorrect.

question.text: Which of the following is a product of glycolysis?

explanation.concept_text: Glycolysis is the first step of aerobic cellular respiration, and it occurs within the cytosol of the cell. It is also the only completely anaerobic step of aerobic cellular respiration. The first step of glycolysis is the phosphorylation of glucose via hexokinase and the hydrolysis of 1 ATP to yield glucose-6-phosphate . Once the first phosphorylation step has completed, glucose-6-phosphate will be converted to fructose-6-phosphate via isomerase. This fructose-6-phosphate will then undergo phosphorylation via phosphofructokinase (PFK) to yield fructose-1,6-bisphosphate. It should be known that this step is the rate-determining step of glycolysis and commits the glucose molecule to glycolysis. The mechanism of glycolysis that follows these steps is not important for your test, however, it is crucial to understand that the net products of glycolysis are 2 pyruvate , 2 NADH , and 2 ATP . Because pyruvate is one of the products of glycolysis, Option E . is the correct answer. CC By 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. PGAL – This option is incorrect. PGAL, also known as 3-phosphoglyceraldehyde, is an intermediate of glycolysis, NOT a product. During glycolysis, once fructose-1,6-bisphosphate is formed, it will further breakdown into PGAL which will then undergo a series of redox reactions to ultimately form pyruvate, NADH, and ATP. Option B. H 2 O and CO 2 – This option is incorrect. Recall that glycolysis is the process by which one molecule of glucose gets broken down to yield a net of 2 pyruvate, 2 NADH, and 2 ATP. While CO 2 and H 2 O are products of aerobic cellular respiration as a whole, they are NOT products of glycolysis specifically. CO 2 gets produced during pyruvate decarboxylation and the Krebs cycle while water is produced during oxidative phosphorylation. Option C. G3P and CO 2 – This option is incorrect . Recall that glycolysis is the process by which one molecule of glucose gets broken down to yield a net of 2 pyruvate, 2 NADH, and 2 ATP. After fructose-1,6-bisphosphate is produced, it will further break down into glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate (G3P), which is an intermediate formed before pyruvate gets produced. Therefore, G3P is an intermediate of glycolysis, NOT a product. Additionally, CO 2 is a product of pyruvate decarboxylation and the Krebs cycle, not glycolysis. Option D. Acetyl CoA – This option is incorrect. Acetyl CoA is one of the products of pyruvate decarboxylation, along with NADH and CO 2 . Pyruvate decarboxylation is the step the immediately follows glycolysis during aerobic cellular respiration. During pyruvate decarboxylation, the pyruvate that’s produced during glycolysis gets decarboxylated to yield Acetyl CoA. Acetyl CoA is NOT a product of glycolysis.

question.text: Which of the following is not present on a eukaryotic DNA strand?

options.label: A.
options.text: A region for ribosomes to bind

correct_answer_text: A region for ribosomes to bind

explanation.concept_text: Recall that DNA and RNA are the two main types of nucleic acids which you should know for your test. As with all macromolecules, DNA is composed of repeating subunits, known as monomers. The monomeric subunits of DNA are known as nucleotides . Recall that nucleotides are a pentose (5-carbon sugar) attached to a nitrogenous base and a single phosphate group. The primary purpose of DNA is to hold the genetic code that’s used as a blueprint to make proteins. First, the DNA strand must be transcribed into a messenger RNA (mRNA) strand. This process is known as DNA transcription . Next, that messenger RNA strand gets translated into a protein with the help of ribosomes! This process is known as translation . The crucial information that we need to understand in order to answer this question is simply that ribosomes do NOT bind to DNA, but rather, they bind to messenger RNA during protein translation. Ribosomes are unable to directly use DNA during protein translation. Instead, ribosomes will bind to an mRNA strand in order to read the strand and translate the corresponding polypeptide chain. Because ribosomes do NOT bind to DNA, it would not make sense for DNA to have a binding site for ribosomes. Therefore, Option A. is the correct answer to this question. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B . A region coding for proteins – This option is incorrect . The primary purpose of DNA is to hold the genetic code that will be used as a blueprint to translate proteins. Within a DNA strand are segments of DNA that will code for a protein, known as genes. These genes will be transcribed into a messenger RNA (mRNA) strand before being translated into a protein. It’s worth noting that in eukaryotes, including humans, only a small percentage of a DNA strand will actually code for a protein. Regardless, coding regions are an integral characteristic of DNA, therefore, this option is incorrect. Option C. A simple sequence repeat of nucleotides – This option is incorrect . Simple sequence repeats (SSRs) are regions of DNA by which a sequence of nucleotides are repeated. The analysis of simple sequence repeats are used as a diagnostic tool for many diseases. Because simple sequence repeats are present on eukaryotic DNA, this option is incorrect. Option D. Non-coding regions – This option is incorrect . The primary purpose of DNA is to hold the genetic code that will be used as a blueprint to translate proteins. Within a DNA strand are segments of DNA that will code for a protein, known as genes. These genes will be transcribed into a messenger RNA (mRNA) strand before being translated into a protein. It’s worth noting that in eukaryotes, including humans, only a small percentage of a DNA strand will actually code for a protein. The segments that do not code for proteins are known as non-coding regions and while they may not directly code for a protein, often times, they serve a separate purpose. One example of this is seen in regulatory elements, such as promoters, enhancers, and silencers, which regulate gene expression. Another example of non-coding regions are introns, which are spliced out during mRNA processing. Because DNA strands possess non-coding regions, this option is incorrect.

question.text: Why do nerve cells differ from skin cells despite both cells having identical genomes?

options.label: D.
options.text: Cells lose sections of their genome to differentiate

options.label: E.
options.text: Lysosomes in each cell dissolve incorrectly expressed proteins

explanation.concept_text: For this question, it is important to note that all eukaryotic cells within a particular organism, with the exception of gametes, carry identical genetic information within their nucleus. So, if that’s the case, how is it possible that there are so many different cell types? The answer to this question stems from the fact that despite having identical genetic information, cells of different type will exhibit differential gene expression and regulation. Nerve cells and skin cells have vastly different functions within an organism and therefore, will activate/suppress certain genes in order to fulfill their required function. In addition to gene expression, other factors such as alternative splicing and epigenetics can play a role in cell differentiation. Because differential expression of structural genes will lead to the emergence of different cell types (such as nerve cells and skin cells), Option B. is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Cells contain different DNA sequences – This option is incorrect. All somatic cells contain identical genetic information. This means that all cells, with the exception of gametes, are made up of the exact same DNA sequences. The reason that different cell types arise is primarily due to differential gene expression leading to the translation of different protein products. Option C. Genome changes during development – This option is incorrect. Fertilization, which is the fusion of egg and sperm nuclei, will lead to the inheritance of the genome from both mother and father. This genome does not change during development. Throughout development, all somatic cells will contain the exact same genetic information and it’s the role of differential gene expression that will lead to cell differentiation. Because the genome is not altered during development, this option is incorrect. Option D. Cells lose sections of their genome to differentiate – This option is incorrect. All somatic cells within a eukaryotic organism contain identical genetic information within their nucleus. Cells do NOT lose sections of their genome in order to differentiate. Instead, it is the result of differential gene expression that leads to the emergence of different cell types. Because cells do not lose sections of their genome during differentiation, this option is incorrect. Option E. Lysosomes in each cell dissolve incorrectly expressed proteins – This option is incorrect. Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles that contain digestive enzymes which function at low pH. These enzymes are used to degrade substances such as bacteria, cell debris, and nutrients. While it is true that lysosomes are capable of degrading proteins that are incorrectly expressed or simply no longer needed within the cell, this is not the cause of cell differentiation.

question.text: A father with muscular dystrophy (X-linked recessive disease) and a mother of an unknown genotype produce a son with muscular dystrophy and a normal daughter. What is the genotype of the mother?

explanation.concept_text: Before getting into the explanation for this question, it is important to first understand some general concepts that the question is asking about. The question asks about muscular dystrophy , an X-linked recessive disease. This means that the allele responsible for causing muscular dystrophy is present on the X chromosome. In addition, we know that muscular dystrophy is a recessive disease. This means that males, which possess one X and one Y chromosome, MUST possess the affected allele (X m ) on their only X chromosome in order for the muscular dystrophy phenotype to be expressed. Females, who possess two X chromosomes, MUST possess the affected allele (X m ) on BOTH of their X chromosomes. That is, females must be homozygous (X m X m ) in order to express the muscular dystrophy phenotype. First, consider the sex chromosomes that the son and daughter must have: XY and XX respectively. We know that each parent must contribute one of these chromosomes. Let’s look at their genotypes below. We know that son must get his Y chromosome from the father and the X chromosome must come from the mother. Because the son has an X-linked recessive disease, this must mean that the son received an affected X chromosome from the mother. For this to be the case, the mother must have at least one chromosome with the muscular dystrophy allele: X m X or X m X m (X m represents the affected chromosome for muscular dystrophy). Next, we know that the father has muscular dystrophy and so his genotype must be X m Y. We know that the daughter is normal. Recall that the daughter must get one X chromosome from the father and one from the mother. The father’s only X chromosome contains the muscular dystrophy allele so the daughter must have received this affected chromosome. However, because the daughter is normal, we know that her other X chromosome must be unaffected so her genotype must be X m X. The normal X chromosome must then come from the mother. From this, we see that the mother contributed an affected X chromosome to the son and an unaffected X chromosome to the daughter. Therefore, the mother’s genotype must be X m X. Therefore, Option C . X m X , is the correct answer. CC By 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. XmY – This option is incorrect . The question is asking us to determine the mother’s genotype. We know that females possess two X chromosomes, NOT one X and one Y chromosome. Therefore, this option is incorrect. Option B. XY – This option is incorrect . The question is asking us to determine the mother’s genotype. We know that females possess two X chromosomes, NOT one X and one Y chromosome. Therefore, this option is incorrect. Option D. XX – This option is incorrect . We know from the information provided that the son has muscular dystrophy.
